subject: Re: Comparing two files on runtime
msgSnippet: Like you our project has the need to compare files and large XML documents and elements. The system is about 95% batch. Several other posts have submitted
messageBody:
Like you our project has the need to compare files and large XML
documents and elements. The system is about 95% batch. Several other
posts have submitted ideas on how you might do this. I wish I had
realized that there were tools out there to do this because I wrote it
all myself. As you can see there are options, so hopefully you will
not need to do all the work that I did.

However, I did come up with a few techniques that you might find
helpful. I keep all of the input files in a directory called TestData.
The structure of this directory is identical to my source directory.
Therefore any test input files required by a.b.c.TestCase1 will be
found in the TestData/a/b/c/TestCase1 directory.

I have a BaseTestCase that has a number of methods that will return
the handle to afile from the current TestCase directory, in the form
of a fileNameString, File, InputStream, etc. to the satisfy the input
requirements of the methods that I am testing. To access the file, you
call the appropriate method and give it the file name (without the
directory structure). The beauty of this approach is that you always
know where you data is and if you refactor your class and move it to
another package, you simply move you TestData directory to the
directory that corresponds to your new package name.

For comparison purposes, I have the identical structure in a directory
called TestResults. Since typically only one file or XML would be
compared per test method, I store the test results in a file with the
same name as the test method, followed by either .txt or .xml. I came
up with the following little trick to get the test method name:

String testMethodName = new Exception().getStackTrace()
[0].getMethodName();
System.out.println(testMethodName);

The first two lines of all of our test methods are always these two
lines. It is very helpful to display the test method name in the
system.out so you figure out which test method sys prints that must be
added from time-to-time to a test method came from. We pass the
testMethodName to the methods in our BaseTestCase that do the file and
XML compares. This class figures out the directory from the class name
and we keep the root directory, which changes dependent upon
environment, in a properties file.

I also added an option in the constructor of the BaseTestCase to
indicate when the compare methods are executed whether they should do
one of the following:
1. compare the files and fail if the prior results not found
2. compare the files if the prior results found, otherwise write the
new results to the file
3. write the new results to the file.

We almost always have option 2 turned on. When the results change and
we verify that the change is valid, we simply delete the old file and
run the test again. It is working very well for us.
